headline: Why Qualcomm’s (QCOM) Long-Term Prospects Shine, Even if the Stock Doesn’t
summary: Qualcomm (QCOM) has underperformed over the past year, declining 26%, primarily due to macroeconomic factors rather than internal company mechanics. Although the company’s fundamentals remain very solid, it has faced some headwinds, such as concerns that its business is too concentrated on Apple (AAPL) for modem revenue, despite its broader operations still being more rooted in the Android ecosystem. Still, that doesn’t stop me from seeing the stock as a long-term Buy—especially since my bullish

headline: QUALCOMM (QCOM) to Acquire Alphawave for $2.4 Billion in Data Center Expansion Push
summary: QUALCOMM Incorporated (NASDAQ:QCOM) is one of the 10 AI Stocks on Wall Street’s Radar. On June 9, the company reported that it has agreed to buy semiconductor company Alphawave IP Group Plc for an estimated $2.4 billion in cash, aiming to expand its technology and key assets for expanding into data centers. headline: AI Chips Update - AI Blueprint Revolutionizes Financial Services With NVIDIA Technology
summary: Dataiku has introduced a new FSI Blueprint, aimed at facilitating the deployment of agentic AI systems within the financial services sector. This blueprint, enhanced by NVIDIA's accelerated computing technologies, supports banking and insurance firms in creating and managing intelligent AI agents at scale, while adhering to industry regulations. Leveraging NVIDIA's NIM microservices, NeMo, and GPU infrastructure, the blueprint offers a secure and modular framework suitable for diverse...

headline: Qualcomm launches AI R&D centre in Vietnam
summary: HANOI (Reuters) -U.S. chipmaker Qualcomm  has launched an artificial intelligence research and development centre in Vietnam, the company said on Tuesday.  Qualcomm said the move is aligned with Vietnam's strategies for AI, semiconductors, and digital transformation, and will focus on transferring technology, ecosystem collaboration and capacity building.  Meeting in Hanoi on Tuesday with Alex Rogers, Qualcomm's President of Global Affairs, Vietnam's top leader To Lam encouraged the company to continue expanding its operations in the country, including its semiconductor and digital infrastructure businesses.
